model_output:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) cognitive architectures are frameworks designed to model and simulate human-like intelligence within machines. These architectures aim to understand and replicate various aspects of cognition, such as perception, reasoning, learning, memory, and problem-solving [2]. The relevance of cognitive architectures to AI research lies in their potential for creating intelligent systems that can demonstrate human-like behavior by imitating the processes underlying human thought. This is crucial in achieving the longstanding objective of passing the Turing Test [1]. Historically, the development of cognitive architectures in AI research evolved from the pursuit of greater breadth and depth in theories of cognition [2]. In the 2000s, definitions and tests of intelligence developed by psychologists served as a foundation for approaching machine intelligence [5]. More recently, theories like the SP theory have been introduced with the aim of integrating and simplifying concepts in computing and cognitive science [2]. The current emphasis on large language models (LLMs) has led to new advancements in AI cognitive architectures. These models possess capabilities to solve diverse tasks and have raised the possibility that they could be considered Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) [1, 3, 4]. References:
